text: we're having pretty severe meeting bloat and ineffective/repetitive/useless meetings with our regularly scheduled internal ones, and i've been tasked with taking the first step of addressing the issue by surveying our team about our meetings. Has anyone dealt with this before? Wondering if anyone has some good questions to ask. So far I'm thinking of going through each weekly meeting and asking "what are the goals of this meeting in your opinion; is the meeting achieving these goals; how could this meeting be improved to accomplish its goals," as well as soliciting a general response on their feelings/thoughts on our internal meetings. Anyone have ideas of how to elicit the most valuable and actionable feedback?

text:
Some questions you can ask:
• How often do your meetings have agendas?
• What are the average length of your meetings?
• Do your meetings run overtime?
• Do you feel like you’re contributing when you’re at that meeting?
• How much of that meeting is spent talking about items not on the agenda?

text:
Jessie, I have absolutely been there (am there). I don’t know how large your team is but within our Content & Comms team (~12 people) we did a recurring meeting audit. We dropped all of our standing meetings and non-managerial 1:1s into a doc, including those w/ other teams. That was a great starting point and helped find some efficiencies with content distribution meetings and processes that the content and social teams were separately involved in.

Company-wide they created and released a guide to “how we work” focused on meetings a couple years ago. This laid out some best practices for inclusion and some standards around providing agendas and pre-work, saying no to meetings, etc. It needs to be reinforced over time if it’s going to work though because meeting culture will tend to creep back in!

text: I don't this challenge ever really stops - it just changes. The most effective method I've ever used - which can be admittedly hard to implement at larger teams - is an agile scrum standup approach. We find meeting bloat tends to come from rabbit hold and side conversations creeping into meetings - where the conversations aren't relevant to the group. If we have a "Scrum master" who can be responsible for saying "let's move that to a separate convo" it helps. Also, we try to stay focused on "what's our plate this week, what's hot, where are you blocked?" And if people stay to that, we tend to keep our meetings tight.

text:
Thanks for the mention <@U020GLH1U10>!!

Yeah - I think that the main thing that’s helped us stay honest is literally asking people to rate the meeting after *every meeting* we have.

If a meeting had it’s purpose and was going well in January… maybe things changed 3 months down the line, be it strategy, project focus, etc. Being able to see the trends of those ratings over time means that if things drop… you can address that immediately in the next meeting and either decide on:

1. What needs to change for this meeting to be a productive use of everyone’s time? (It could be meeting less frequently, changing the agenda, etc)
2. Has the purpose and goal of this meeting changed? (Let the answer here dictate the agenda)
3. Do we still need to meet in general? (if the answer is no… there’s an extra bit of time back on your calendar).

text:
In my role, I have the fortune of spending about six hours a week in weekly synchs, plus ad-hoc meetings for projects and such

What we do for each sync is that we have an agenda Google Doc that our program manager keeps up to date with topics. The Product Marketing Manager then determines how much time to spend on each topic or if it should be discussed offline.

Then when we meet, we go through the agenda and if we get through everything early (which is rare), we'll get time back. If we find there's not much to discuss, we'll just cancel the meeting and handle discussions offline.

If we find that we're not spending much time on a market or such on a recurring basis, then we'll just merge it into another meeting to be more efficient.

Over the past year that I've been attending these recurring meetings, the topics/formats have continuously evolved to fit our needs organically, and we've managed to consolidate quite a few meetings.

My team however is in a unique situation as we own global product messaging, so we tend to be very hands on with our stakeholders and need close alignment. In other cases we only have formal meetings when there's a significant debrief such as an initial feature launch or such.
